title: Will there be a lethal confrontation between the national military forces, militia, and/or law enforcement personnel of Taiwan and the People's Republic of China before 15 December 2020?
preds: Downgrading for time...only about a week remains and no reporting suggests unusually heightened tensions.
Short timeline, COVID, and no news suggesting increased tensions right now.

There is no extraordinary activity between Taiwan and China at this time.  It seems highly unlikely a lethal confrontation will occur in the next couple weeks.  Furthermore, the US State Department recently reaffirmed its support for Taiwan's "freedom and independence," (https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/policy/defense-national-security/us-affirms-taiwans-freedom-and-independence-despite-chinas-sovereignty-claims), a fairly clear signal of U.S. support to Taiwan which should dissuade China from taking overt action.  My only hesitation from an even lower forecast value is the sheer number of actors included in the question.
with the remaining time, my estimation of the chance has fallen to just under half a percent so rounding down to 0.

Use of weapons on targets above the waterlines has been oked for the PLA Navy.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/_2uXnPuwGsw" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>
Still too many provocations not to rule out a mid-air near miss.

There appears to be a low chance of purposeful lethal confrontation between the PRC and Taiwan between now and 15 Dec. Numerous articles have pointed to the intensifying overt relationship between Taiwan and the US, and the worsening relationship between the PRC and the US. To attack Taiwan may be a bet the PRC doesn’t want to make in the next 30 days in fear of bringing the US into the mix (and Japan, Korea, and Guam, and other states with US basing). The economic ties between Taiwan and the PRC still appear fairly substantial; neither side likely wants to deny their state the benefits of those relationships.  However, due to the increase in ‘close calls’ between Taiwanese, PRC, and US forces in the area, and the PRC's use of live-fire exercises during a US-Taiwan meeting, an inadvertent lethal confrontation may occur. An outside chance of the PRC flexing military power during the US’s presidential transition may also exist. Support:
https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-34729538
https://thediplomat.com/2020/10/chinas-military-incursions-around-taiwan-arent-a-sign-of-imminent-attack

China's New Pressure on Taiwan in the South China Sea - Foreign Policy Research Institute
https://www.fpri.org/article/2020/11/chinas-new-pressure-on-taiwan-in-the-south-china-sea/
Mon, 16 Nov 2020 15:42:54 GMT China attempts to deny Taiwan access to strategic islands, which is a new move.

Updated 20201123 Lethal confrontation being interpreted to mean the death of at least one person. The statement today, by U.S. national security adviser Robert O’Brien, in support of Philippines and Vietnam (see https://reut.rs/396M5mT) suggests that a lethal confrontation within the time frame of this question is now even less than it was 24 hours ago. Trying to take account of any possible confirmation bias, my view is that this statement by O'Brien was clearly intended to be a warning to PRC / PLA that in spite of current local situation in US in the aftermath of the election, the overall policy of maintaining freedom of navigation in the area is unchanged. See also the recent comments by U.S. Marine Corps Commandant Gen. David Berger at a meeting with Japan's Suga (https://bit.ly/3lYpahm) which I see as further reinforcement of US policy in the area. Updated 20201122 This unconfirmed visit by a high level, 2 star US Admiral may vex China; see https://reut.rs/3nPBKAa. However, I doubt China will publicly take any direct action to reassert its claims against Taiwan. As below, not while the Trump administration is still in office, even if only by a token of the remaining time he has in office. Equally, considering some of the actions the Trump administration has taken since the election, one could wager that this high level visit is another 'rash' Trump directed event.  Whether China would intentionally take any action that could be stage managed as an accident for the international media, is however, a question that cannot be completely ruled out in the light of this visit. However, in the remaining time of this question, I doubt it is feasible. More likely when the new administration takes office, assuming a Biden administration. At 20201117 Although China claims Taiwan is part of China and China's PLA planes have, on a couple of occasions in 2020 crossed the Taiwan Straits centre line, on the basis of a 'lethal confrontation' meaning at least one death, I do not believe China will risk an all out confrontation with Taiwan or any of its military or milita while the Trump administration is in office. @sebawi - congratulations on The Economist World 2020 Challenge
Possible. China is watching to see if there's a 'moment'. More likely there will be a clash with China and India but this is one other alternative.
Less likely due to time passed and no change in political situation noticed

Any deaths between military forces (militia and LEO's included) will be purely accidental in nature, most likely because of one or both sides having aggressive pilots involved in a mid-air collision similar to the Hainan Island incident between the PLAAF fighter and the American Recon plane twenty years ago.

US Speeds Arms Sales for Taiwan as Island Revamps China Strategy - VOA Asia
https://www.voanews.com/east-asia-pacific/us-speeds-arms-sales-taiwan-island-revamps-china-strategy
Fri, 06 Nov 2020 14:15:00 GMT

I figure if China hopes to invade Taiwan at any time within the next 3 years it will be within the next 3 weeks. So I give it a 1 in 33 chance China will invade over the next 3 years. Give it zero chance after Feb 1st.
Worst case scenario among some analysts is China invades Taiwan during a protracted undecided US election under the theory the executive will be too distracted by the election outcome to respond.

China is gaining influence over Taiwan through soft power means. With their increasing control over international institutions to shape the global view, growing economic advantage over the region, this means that Taiwan would lack the regional and international support required. If a lethal confrontation happens, it would likely be instigated by a Taiwanese group acting outside the control of the Taiwanese government.

Anti-ship missile sale could frustrate a Chinese invasion of Taiwan - Business Insider - Business Insider
https://www.businessinsider.com/sale-of-missiles-to-taiwan-could-frustrate-a-chinese-invasion-2020-10
Wed, 28 Oct 2020 14:41:32 GMT China's Real Invasion of Taiwan Has Already Started - The Daily Beast
https://www.thedailybeast.com/chinas-real-invasion-of-taiwan-has-already-started-through-the-united-front
Wed, 28 Oct 2020 08:57:00 GMT
Decreasing because of time gone by

Decent background on this and broader South China Sea...
https://www.nippon.com/en/in-depth/d00627/

Increasing my forecast to take into account the recent provocations by the PRC (especially aerial intrusions) plus an increase in inflammatory language from the CCP (https://www.spytalk.co/p/is-china-preparing-to-attack-taiwan). The possibility of an accidental death by collision has increased. The likelihood of an actual invasion is less clear. There are so many countervailing arguments to factor into any decision that it seems unlikely (but not impossible) the General Secretary and Standing Committee will decide to act. Time is on their side. If China were to invade an island, the aftermath of the US election would be an good time to consolidate that military gain. This needs to be watched closely.

Two great reads on the worsening Taiwan-China situation:
https://www.economist.com/china/2020/10/22/chinas-half-loving-half-threatening-pitch-to-taiwan-doesnt-work
https://www.nbcnews.com/news/china/tiny-taiwan-caught-middle-u-s-china-battle-supremacy-n1244521

China is occupied in constant transgressions of the US defined median line between the mainland and Taiwan that it refuses to recognise.
The CCP has been vocal in that its aim is to recover the island and return it to China and appears to be conducting psychological warfare in preparation for a full-scale invasion.
According the you tube clip the window of opportunity in 2020 has passed due to weather conditions that prevail at this time of year but will reopen March 2021.
I will suggest that a lethal confrontation in 2020 has limited value to China that would raise, even further, awareness in the US and Taiwan to increase preparedness in terms of weaponry.
It will be a different scenario in 2021.  https://youtu.be/ECbG6uk910w https://www.taiwannews.com.tw/en/news/4025981  https://edition.cnn.com/2020/09/21/asia/taiwan-china-warplanes-median-line-intl-hnk-scli/index.html  https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3103985/taiwan-under-psychological-attack-chinese-warplanes-cross
Irrelevant to the Q but quite an incredible story nonetheless: https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-54605976

Good overview of the current situation: "2020 has seen Taiwan's unexpected resurgence on the international stage ... Beijing has responded with anger and shows of force, including military drills and numerous incursions into Taiwanese airspace ... 'Taiwan is one of those flash points that has never flashed,' writes Michael Schuman for The Atlantic. But now, says Schuman, the conditions appear to be ripe for possible conflict." https://www.axios.com/china-taiwan-conflict-4e3cd357-22de-463f-851c-4275884b0b6e.html This is an excellent broader analysis on the future of US foreign policy with respect to Taiwan: https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2020/10/15/taiwan-china-trump-tensions/

Excellent article by The Economist, with some relevant tidbits: "Last year Xi Jinping, China’s leader, declared unification to be an 'inevitable requirement for the historical rejuvenation of the Chinese nation'. The PLA has stepped up pressure on Taiwan in recent months, sending warplanes across the 'median line' that long served as an unofficial maritime boundary and holding large naval drills off several parts of Taiwan’s coast ... China’s defence budget, merely double Taiwan’s at the end of the 1990s, is now 25 times greater ... American intelligence officials do not think that China is about to unleash this firepower. The PLA’s amphibious fleet has grown slowly in recent years. China has never held even a single exercise on the scale that would be required for a D-Day-type campaign." https://www.economist.com/asia/2020/10/10/defending-taiwan-is-growing-costlier-and-deadlier So, tensions b/w China and Taiwan are heightened but all-out war seems very unlikely in the near future. However, heightened tensions might still be enough to result in an *accidental* lethal confrontation. The crowd thinks there is an only 1-in-50 chance (2%) of such a lethal confrontation occurring between now and 15 Dec — I am not that confident.

Although Taiwan is rebuilding its military and has a resolute leader in Tsai Ing-wen power it remains unlikely that China and Taiwan will engage in a lethal confrontation before December 15, 2020, because at this time the “PRC appears willing to defer the use of military force as long as it considers that unification with Taiwan could be negotiated over the long-term and the costs of conflict outweigh the benefits.

Winnie the Pooh is really after Taiwan’s hunny... China is drifting slightly domestically. Even if no action, ramping up the rhetoric will preoccupy many. Love (sarcasm) the Chinese revisionist history re Korean War.
https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/05/world/asia/china-propaganda-united-states.html
Although Taiwan is rebuilding its military, it's doubtful that either China or Taiwan would engage in a lethal confrontation in the next 60 days.
Dropping down, seems unlikely and time has passed.
Commander in Chief now in circumstance... https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-10-02/trump-says-he-and-first-lady-tested-positive-for-coronavirus
While it's possible that China would test new leadership, between the election and inauguration it would be a huge gamble. A gamble they don't need to take if playing the long game.

https://www.rfi.fr/en/international/20200925-is-mainland-china-gearing-up-for-an-invasion-of-taiwan
Q: Is mainland China gearing up for an invasion of Taiwan? 
A: Probably not

Winnie the Pooh is after “hunny” in Taiwan. Keeping Taiwanese Air Force on their toes (and tired). 
https://www.reuters.com/article/taiwan-security-idUSKCN26H08Z

"Taiwan is not pursuing formal diplomatic ties with the United States for now, but there is 'a lot' of room to further strengthen relations, Foreign Minister Joseph Wu said in an interview after unprecedented visits by two senior U.S. officials ... In August, U.S. Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar traveled to Taiwan, and last week Under Secretary of State Keith Krach visited the island. They were the highest ranking U.S. officials to travel to Taiwan since Washington cut formal diplomatic relations with Taipei in 1979 to establish ties with Beijing ... The cozier relationship between Washington and Taipei has angered Beijing. While Krach was in Taiwan, China ordered dozens of military planes to make forays across the median line that divides the Taiwan Strait, in a bid to rattle Taipei." https://www.npr.org/2020/09/22/915818283/formal-ties-with-u-s-not-for-now-says-taiwan-foreign-minister

Currently no change, but continued airspace violations by the PLAAF could lead to an accident and escalation in the near term.   https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/sep/22/taiwan-tells-china-back-off-official-denies-marine-boundary

China is behaving more aggressively and hardening the language and increased incursions into Taiwan airspace by its air force.
China has for the first time gained a technological superiority over Taiwan in its military capability.
One potential conflict could be for the PLA to take over the Taiwan islands of Kinmen Matsu and Penghu as a test of capability, Taiwanese resolve and world reaction. 
A Chinese invasion of Taiwan would be bloody and expensive, but they would ignore a backlash if it consisted only of rhetoric and would shrug off International isolation as the world cannot distance itself from China economically (yet).
Xi Jinping has indicated his impatience to resolve the Taiwan issue.
 The resolve of the US would be tested as to react militarily could lead to war and to ignore it would be to accept the authority of the Chinese. Both dangerous.
A precursor to military action would be heightened cyberattacks on the institutions of Taiwan and China has been increasing those.
Hong Kong has been subjugated and Taiwan remains the last piece to make China, one.
The only probability here is that China will eventually attempt (and probably succeed) in gaining control over Taiwan. The only question is when?
The timeline is quite short and I propose there will be a sure but steady build up over a period of time. https://www.businessinsider.com/chinas-military-buildup-attitude-toward-taiwan-raises-conflict-fears-2020-9  https://www.ft.com/content/e3462762-3080-11ea-9703-eea0cae3f0de https://www.pf.org.tw/files/6510/A73CE07D-0D72-4AF8-9075-98A1CB188DA1  https://www.brookings.edu/blog/order-from-chaos/2020/08/20/chinas-dangerous-taiwan-temptation/  https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/08/12/china-increases-military-pressure-on-taiwan-the-view-from-taipei/

It is likely we'll see more and more provocations by Chinese aircrafts in the future [1] - possibly on similar frequency levels of "interaction" by Chinese and Japanese aircrafts currently [2,3].  [1] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-taiwan-china-idUSKCN26B06I
[2] https://edition.cnn.com/2020/07/28/asia/japan-china-fighter-jet-scrambles-intl-hnk-dst/index.html
[3] https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2020/09/21/asia-pacific/china-taiwan-buffer-zone-war/

China would likely prefer to deal with Biden (consistency). Winnie the Pooh unlikely to be too provocative prior to election results. That does allow a month window before close of question, however. Still keeping it low.

"Multiple Chinese aircraft flew across the mid-line of the Taiwan Strait and into Taiwan’s air defence identification zone on Friday and Saturday, causing Taiwan to scramble jets to intercept ... The exercises took place as U.S. Undersecretary for Economic Affairs Keith Krach was in Taipei, the most senior State Department office to come in four decades ... Further friction seems likely as Taiwan and the United States continue to deepen relations, with Taiwan angling for a free trade agreement." https://www.reuters.com/article/us-taiwan-china-idUSKCN26B06I
Increasing my very low probabilities a little bit, because I realize I'm not really that well calibrated for low percentages.

Increased cooperation and coordination between Tiawanese and American Governments is straining already tense Sino-American relations.  Increased political tensions tend to lead to increased military action in the form of drills and movement of forces to areas adjacent to potential battle areas.  Increased proximity of military forces in a highly charged political atmosphere tends to lead to an accidents that could spark a potential conflict. https://www.taiwannews.com.tw/en/news/4009974

I read in the following essay regarding China invading Taiwan that "there are only a few months every year in which such an invasion could occur". Does anyone know which months? My guess would be summer months, but I don't know for sure. https://scholars-stage.blogspot.com/2020/09/why-i-fear-for-taiwan.html?m=1

Revising slightly upward on recent news: "Taiwan sounded the alarm over China conducting large-scale joint air and naval exercises inside its air defence buffer zone, a move Taipei denounced as a 'severe provocation' and a threat to regional peace and stability ... At a rare press conference called on Thursday night, Taiwan’s defence ministry said almost two dozen Chinese military aircraft and seven naval ships had operated between 7am and noon on Wednesday and Thursday in an area between Pratas, a Taiwan-controlled atoll in the South China Sea, and Taiwan’s south-western coast ... The drill confirms concerns in Taipei that the People’s Liberation Army would ratchet up military pressure closer to Taiwan’s borders once the coronavirus crisis receded in China. A Taiwanese former senior military officer said the Chinese move was the most serious threat to Taiwan’s security since 1996, when Beijing fired missiles into waters just north and south of Taiwan." https://www.ft.com/content/9bf1c039-3222-4aa7-be37-6f01afc41ef2
Agree with crowd. Neither wants a war at the moment. Xi, however, has a vision for Taiwan being under his wing. He may threaten with military and economic might to keep them as close as possible.

I do not think that there will be a military confrontation between the ROC and the PRC in the near future, due to the PRC increasing hostilities with India, and because of the lingering effects of the COVID-19 outbreak.

"Of late the number of naval exercises China has conducted has caused alarm—all the more so at a time of worsening relations between China and America on a number of fronts, including American policy towards Taiwan." https://www.economist.com/asia/2020/09/03/to-chinas-alarm-america-modestly-upgrades-ties-with-taiwan

A good read on state of Taiwan and American support...
https://www.economist.com/node/21791417?frsc=dg%7Ce
My own view - Winnie the Pooh’s military isn’t ready (despite making huge stride re amphibious landings etc.). As dictator for life (imo) Winnie can wait for a subsequent administration - either Biden or in four years which will be more accommodating to China. 
While possibility of accident exists (hence 1%) and China is becoming more bellicose, this will be a play for time as China gets stronger and USA - while strong - won’t keep pace in Pacific.
(+3%) - China loving a ruck at the moment.
Going up a little bit seeing as how India and China couldn't successfully negotiate their border

This is more of a possibility than is commonly appreciated as President Trump could recognise Taiwanese sovereignty in a bid to stoke high USA-China cold war tensions before the November 2020 US election. His recognition of Jerusalem as the capital of Israel and meeting with Kim Jong Un show a capacity for shock moves like this. Unfortunately this could easily spiral out of control due to his lack of nuanced understanding of the regional politics; China is a pragmatic police state with a long term view and no apparent appetite for conflict but this would represent a line that could not be crossed without retaliation.

Say civilization collapses and you are short the stock market. If you were short the market, you were right, but you won't to get paid. If China and Taiwan come into lethal conflict, good chance I won't care what my Brier score is.

"Tsai has complained of increased Chinese military drills and on Thursday warned of the risk of accidental conflict." https://www.reuters.com/article/us-taiwan-security/taiwan-unveils-f-16-maintenance-hub-as-china-tensions-build-idUSKBN25O0CS
I am retreating to a more comfortable forecast after the war games.

Adjusting back down. China has a superior force staged to invade, but has to cross the straight. Taiwan has nearly all it's male population in the reserves which could be called up.  The official US position is in support of China's one China policy, but I tend to think that the United States would support Taiwan in an invasion. And I think China believes that too. and Chinese and Taiwan troops are not likely to casually run into each other like China and India might. So the only possibility for a fatality would be a full-on invasion. Also, China has other enemies in the region that might take advantage.
War games cause me to increase from my rock bottom forecast.

+6 - Recent US visit and China drills have encouraged the Taiwanese to increase their defence spend for upcoming year, the language in Source 1 is quite inflammatory. Therefore raising slightly.  However, the timeline is key indicator for me and with HK, India, Australia, US all having issues with China, I cannot see China going for it within this timeframe. Source 1: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-taiwan-defence/taiwan-to-raise-defence-spending-as-china-details-combat-drills-idUSKCN2590BC

China is having live fire drills off Taiwan. US is doing this: https://www.zerohedge.com/geopolitical/us-moves-b-2-stealth-bombers-closer-china-pla-expands-live-fire-drills-taiwan
A mistake could lead to war. US is poking China. China is more aggressive. What could go wrong. I am too low given these events as it does not seem there is much dialogue. I doubt either side wants war but that has not stopped humans in some circumstances. China probably will not do anything as who knows what Trump might do? Nuke em?

Increasing my likelihood due to the recent buildup of amphibious tanks and mobile rocket launchers at the China border and due to the recent live-fire exercises by China. This may be just to appease a certain faction within China though.  Also keep in mind that if you go to the United States state department web page for Taiwan it clearly states that the US official position is still to support the one-China policy that Taiwan is under the ownership of the PRC. If missiles started flying though I could see the US taking Taiwan's position. That would mean a sudden change of policy and war with the only country actually a threat to the US though.
https://www.state.gov/countries-areas/taiwan/

This is my take on this question: The national military forces, militia, and/or law enforcement personnel of the PRC and the Republic of China do not come face to face like, say, those of China and India, China and the Philippines or the US and Iran. Any provocation in the Taiwan Strait by either side would be extremely serious in the light of China's threat to retake Taiwan, and will almost inevitably draw in the US. Therefore, it is a very long shot. Due to its perceived strength from the Covid-19 crisis vis-a-vis other nations, there is not enough pressure on CPC leadership to do anything drastic with regards to Taiwan before Dec 15th this year.

Increasing likelihood due to China building up amphibious tanks and missile launchers near Taiwan. 
https://www.zerohedge.com/geopolitical/china-mobilizes-invasion-craft-coast-near-taiwan-amid-high-level-us-meeting-taipei

"U.S. Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar will lead a delegation to Taiwan on Sunday to meet with senior Taiwanese officials in a rare high-profile visit to the island. Planned discussions will focus on the global response to the COVID-19 pandemic, but the visit comes as tensions between Washington and Beijing have rapidly escalated. It is expected to provoke a strong reaction from China ... In advance of Sunday’s visit, China threatened to take 'strong countermeasures in response to the U.S. behavior.' ... The meeting is also expected to involve discussions on the broader U.S.-Taiwanese relationship." https://foreignpolicy.com/2020/08/07/u-s-officials-to-hold-high-level-talks-with-taiwan-as-tensions-with-china-worsen/
Given economic downturn China probably does not want a big war at the moment.
Lowering. Doubt China would want the instability or cost of attacking Taiwan. They might be tempted due to US confusing policies.
Selecet 5% as a hunch, wanted to update up or down regarding the crowd forecast. As it is also at 5% sticking with that number for now.

Once the U.S. cuts the supply of U.S. dollars to Hong Kong, the latter's foreign exchange reserves will dry out to the point that its linked exchange rate system can no longer function, causing the Hong Kong dollar to depreciate as well as the Renminbi. When this happens, foreign companies will withdraw from the Special Administrative Region with their capital.

Source 1: Looks like China and Taiwan are heading for economic stand-off via Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA); despite my recent forecast which showed China had increased their fly-overs in Taiwan airspace, the below article also brings to light the financial reality ($149 billion trade relationship). Lethal confrontation is therefore unlikely, without considering the fact Taiwan recently bought so much defence: Source 2: The Taiwan Relations Act signed that same year allows the US to supply Taiwan with defence equipment, and Donald Trump’s administration has expanded military and diplomatic ties with the island, prompting protests from Beijing.
The White House has approved more than US$5 billion in arms sales to Taiwan since 2017. The deals include the sale of 108 American-made M1A2T Abrams tanks and help to build an F-16 fighter jet maintenance centre.
The latest agreement is the US$620 million maintenance package for Taiwan’s Patriot Advanced Capability-3 surface-to-air missiles. Therefore, whilst it is of course possible that China may see their chance to strike with the US firmly eyeballing a COVID issue. Yet the reality that Taiwan would overreact from any antagonism, plus there is more than Taiwan as a player here: Source 2: “The PLA is very clear that once a war with Taiwan breaks out, their opponent will not just be the Taiwanese military, but the US-Japan alliance and other allies in the region,” said Zhou Chenming, a researcher from the Yuan Wang, a Beijing-based military science and technology institute.
The PLA was confident that a combined force of its aircraft-carrier groups, air force and land-based missiles was a “strong shield” to prevent the US and other fleets from entering the Taiwan Strait, Zhou said.
Still, a full-scale seaborne invasion of Taiwan would be a huge risk and some observers believe Beijing will try to impose a short, limited campaign to force the Taipei authorities to negotiate, while using its initial advantage in air power to keep US forces at bay. Source 1: https://www.voanews.com/east-asia-pacific/taiwan-preps-possible-end-landmark-trade-deal-china
Source 2: https://www.scmp.com/news/china/military/article/3094177/how-beijings-red-lines-over-taiwan-could-lead-war-us

I think a full invasion of Taiwan is likely to happen in the next few years, but 15 December is too soon. Having said that, if there is a chaotic outcome to the US presidential election, China might take its chance. Also, a small but deadly confrontation such as that which occurred on the Indian border cannot be ruled out.
China is deliberately up setting many nations just pushing the envelope with words thats as far as they will go for the present

https://twitter.com/frontalassault1/status/1284417317661704192?s=21
https://twitter.com/joshiunn/status/1285787423335563264?s=21
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-hongkong-security-taiwan-idUSKCN24I0UM
Can Xi afford to lose control of the illusion Taiwan is part of China? Watch for some action  in the South China Sea by China to see if they can get Taiwan to go back to pretending.

This has to be raised considering what is going on in the Taiwan straight. https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/taiwan-says-threat-of-military-clash-with-china-is-on-the-rise/2020/07/22/6f6da4c8-cc0c-11ea-99b0-8426e26d203b_story.html

Okay, @DelapsusAngelus below points out an article ( https://www.voanews.com/east-asia-pacific/voa-news-china/china-sends-8-military-planes-taiwan-airspace-analysts-see-move ) that says the Chinese did eight of these military aircraft scrambles toward Taiwan in June, twice as many as I was expecting on a monthly basis when I made my last prediction (on May 10, https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1031675 ). I am accordingly doubling my estimate, from 1% to 2%. Any one of these incidents is very unlikely to result in a fatal confrontation, but that's still a nonzero risk each time.  Play stupid games enough times, you win stupid prizes, as we saw on the China-India border.

Raising current forecast as this indicates there is some provocation recently:  https://www.voanews.com/east-asia-pacific/voa-news-china/china-sends-8-military-planes-taiwan-airspace-analysts-see-move However, I still believe this is unlikely to happen in this time period as there is so much activity around China and my feeling it is likely retaliation for the recent US arms sale to Taiwan.

Why would there be a lethal exchange between Taiwan and the PRC and to whose advantage would it be?
No advantage to Taiwan who have been preparing for invasion for the last 70 years against overwhelming odds.
Both sides are armed with first class weaponry.
China wants to regain Taiwan into the authority of the mainland for two reasons:
a)	China’s determination that Taiwan is a part of and belongs to the mainland and
b)	China does want a militarised island lying off its coast with and supported by potential enemies.
A military solution to Chinese demands would prove to be expensive both in lives and economics and localised skirmish resulting in a lethal outcome would not be helpful. A dispute involving fishing boats is assumed to not involve the military. A more likely scenario would be a cyber war attacking Taiwan’s systems of government, industry and business with an emphasis on persuading the populace of its errors would provide a non-lethal battle.
Given the sensitivity and volatility of the region, a legal confrontation is unlikely as great care will be taken to avoid any accidental outbreaks.

From what I can tell there have been 2 lethal conflicts since the PRC was formed in 1949. Although both Taiwan and China were involved in the Vietnam war on opposing sides there was no direct conflict from what I have read. It's around 6 months until this question resolves so I'd say the base rate is about 1-2%. I have listed below factors which I believe could make conflict more or less likely: More Likely:
- China is conducting military exercises close to Taiwan and has militia close to its border. With sabre rattling of this nature it would not take much to incite a skirmish where lives are lost.
- Parties and individuals in favour of independence are in power in Taiwan.
- The West is distracted by Covid-19 and may be unable to oppose any Chinese aggression in the region.
- With tensions high in Hong Kong and it looking increasingly likely that China may take full control of the region, it may be that the PRC will decide to 'kill two birds with one stone' and annex Taiwan as well. Less Likely:
- Although the base rate stands at 1.5% there has not been any lethal conflict between the two sides since 1958. Since international relations and the stability of the region have improved in the last 50 years it is likely that the true probability or base rate is significantly less than 1.5%.
- The history of relations between the two sides has ebbed and flowed between peaceful cooperation and guarded aggression since 1960. The heightened hostility of the last year may not necessarily be any worse than when relations have soured and thawed in the past.
- Any invasion or lethal conflict with Taiwan would undoubtedly further sour Chinese relations with the rest of the world. Since China's prosperity depends on maintaining trade and cooperation with the West it is unlikely that it would do anything that could lead to significant international condemnation. Considering the points above I do think that lethal conflict is more likely at the minute than the base rate would suggest. However, I do not think that it is twice as likely as normal and I am therefore going to say that there is a 2% chance of lethal conflict occurring before 15th December.

As far as I can find, there has been no lethal confrontation between the two since 1958. 15 December 2020 is seven months from today - a very short time in the scale of long-standing cross-strait tensions, so my initial estimate is very low (1%). I see little reason it would be in China's interest to initiate direct hostilities rather than exert its considerable ongoing diplomatic pressure, even under current conditions of heightened tension and with the rest of the world distracted by COVID-19. However, I agree with LMag below that there is a larger risk of small-scale conflict arising through e.g. a naval confrontation or an overreaction to a military exercise. So I am putting my forecast up an additional 2%.

Given China's current aggressive posture and defensiveness regarding any perceived responsibility for COVID-19 I believe there is a slightly better than 1-in-10 chance of a lethal confrontation between China and Taiwan this year, most likely to come in the form of a naval engagement in the strait. The decisive factors appear to me to be: 1) the level of crisis within the United States due to COVID, 2) the level of global hostility directed at China over COVID's outbreak, 3) China's domestic stability. I believe there a reasonable potential with COVID-19 that the US finds itself in additional outbreaks and even deeper economic crises over the remainder of the year, rendering it either unable to totally disinterested in backing Taiwan against anything other than an all out invasion. At the same time global hostility to China could grow drastically to the point that China feels the need to exert some show of force as a subtle/not-so-subtle reminder of its power and that aggression towards the country or the CCP does not come without consequences. The ideal show of force would be explicitly martial, but implicitly economical. It would not be difficult for the Chinese navy to have some sort of "hostile" encounter with a Taiwanese vessel that could serve as a pretext for the Chinese Navy to close the strait temporarily. It seems reasonable that a potential hostile encounter that might precipitate such a crisis would involve a fatality.  This would allow the Chinese to flex their military might while also directly reminding the globe that in a world where the US has become internally focused, and either unable to or disinterested in projecting power in places like the Taiwan Strait, that China is the proverbial "indispensable man". China's domestic political picture could greatly impact this situation further that it is not entirely clear to me in what manner. I am not sure whether greater domestic upheaval would make the Chinese leadership more likely to attempt power projections in the Taiwan Strait or less likely but my general feeling is more likely. Greater domestic tranquility in China I believe would make any possible violent episode in the strait less likely. As such I believe any additional significant outbreaks of COVID in China over the next several months could slightly increase the potential for a lethal encounter.

Reasons for confrontation:
- Due to stronger support for independence in HK and TW, China will try to put pressure on them, as evidenced by more recent military drills and informal confrontations.
- Their traditional military supporter, the US, is weaker due to Covid-19, whereas China has already mostly recovered. The president is also less supportive of foreign military efforts compared to his predecessors, which may embolden China.
- TW may also feel more pressured to assert their independence as international allies are increasingly switching allegiance to China. Reasons against confrontation:
- Despite increasing aggression from China since the 2016 Taiwanese election results, there has not yet been any lethal confrontations. Historically there has been only 1 in the past half-century or so, giving this question a base rate of under 1% over 6 months.
- China likes to conduct drills and displays to show their might, but they rarely want to provoke anger through a direct military confrontation. They prefer indirect methods, e.g. arrests of political activists. Conclusion: Despite increasing military displays, neither China nor Taiwan want a direct confrontation. However, not ruling out the possibility of an accident.
Will also be looking for changes in Xi Jinping's rhetoric on this issue, in case this issue gets used as a distraction from the Covid-19 crisis in China.

The last time there was an incident that would qualify under this question (PRC vs. ROC, military/militia/law enforcement on both sides, at least one fatality) was September 22, 1958.  So, the base rate is for the last 60 years is "zero times per month", which then multiplied by the seven months of the question, is 0%. On the other hand, we have had a number of cases since the election of China sending military aircraft toward Taiwan and the Taiwanese scrambling to meet them (see also https://thediplomat.com/2020/04/chinas-worrying-military-exercises-near-taiwan/ for an account).   These sorts of confrontations do carry risk of accident, as we saw in the 2001 Hainan Island incident ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hainan_Island_incident ).  On the other hand, the risk is relatively low (if I remember how often they happened in the Cold War correctly), and I think the outer limit on number of scrambles over the next seven months is about one a week, given the frequency so far. So, my "confidence range" is roughly 0% to 2%.  I would not be particularly surprised by a fatal incident, but I don't expect one, either.
